bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, May 31, 1899
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: No. 31, Consular Series. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, May 31, 1899.

p.add: INDEX BUREAU REC'D 7 '99 DEPT OF STATE

div1.p: Owen L. W. Smith, To Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State Washington.
Subject. The arrival, suffering and condition of these families of the late Oklahoma emigration, stranded in Jersey City.
Synopsis. Anderson White, WIlliam House and Joe Brown and families, late of the King Fisher County, Oklahoma, arrived April 29, 1899, three dead
No. 31, Consular Series. Legation of the United States Monrovia Liberia; May 31, 1899.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to transmit to you the intelligence, that three families; viz, Anderson White, and wife; Joe Brown and wife; and William House, wife and two children and his wifes stepfather, Mause Hart consisting of nine persons of the Hawes Emigration; late of King Fisher County Oklahoma, that was stranded at Jersey City, recently; reached Monrovia April 29, 1899. Since their arrival the

the entire nine persons grown and 2 children have been critically ill with the African fever. On May 16, one of the number; a four year old child of House's family died. At the time of the death of the child, both the father and the mother of the child were helplessly sick in the same room. On May the 24th the mother of the child, House's wife died. On May 25, 1899, Mause Hart, stepfather to House's wife died!

House and small son in same room are improving. Joe Brown and wife; Anderson White and wife, are improving. White, though very sick has been able to keep his feet. I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith M. R. and C. G.
